description: In this lecture a number of state of the art concepts of 3D environments are explained in a systematic way. In particular the lecture contains topics such as: the architecture of graphics hardware, low- and high-level APIs, OpenGL and DirectX, interactive reflection and refraction, methods to simulate shadow, an introduction to radiometric quantities, radiosity, irradiance volumes, precomputed radiance transfer, ambient occlusion, terrain rendering and terrain synthesis, hair and fur rendering, and high dynamic range imaging.
name: Advanced Image Synthesis

description: Cloud computing, web applications and mobile applications.
name: Cloud, Web & Mobile

description: distributed systems and distributed algorithms.
name: Distributed Systems

description: statistics, big data, machine learning, data/text mining, information visualization, visual analytics, and recommender systems.
name: Learning Analytics

description: Transition systems, behavioral equivalences: language equivalence, bisimulation, Process calculi - CCS, Petri nets (partial order techniques), Graph transformation systems
name: Modeling of Concurrent Systems

description: hot topics and the state-of-the-art in digital games research.
name: Digital Games Research

description: concepts, principles, and methods in current client and server-side Web technologies
name: Advanced Web Technologies

description: teaches the algorithms used to program a computer to generate images of a geometric models with associated appearance properties.
name: Computer Graphics

description: The fundamentals of both topics, Game Architecture and Game Design
name: Game Architecture and Design

description: search engines, information retrieval, information behavior
name: Information Retrieval

description: intelligent tutoring systems, interactive and technology-enhanced learning and teaching environments and online learning platforms.
name: Intelligent Learning Environments

description: advanced topic on understanding, designing and evaluating interactice systems.
lecturer:
Prof. Dr-Ing. Michael Prilla
 Dr. Sebastian Büttner
name: Interaktive Systeme

description: to provide an introduction to the subject area of ​​the "Internet of Things" (IoT), in which billions of embedded systems (sensors, actuators) continuously make data about the real world available on the Internet in real time.
name: Internet of Things: Protocols and System Software

description: Mathematical Optimization Methods for Graphics
name: Lineare und Diskrete Optimierung mit Anwendungen auf Graphen

description:
Data flow analysis (fixed point theory, monotone frameworks, worklist algorithm, application examples: compiler construction, Java bytecode verifier)
Fundamentals of abstract interpretation (Galois connections, safe approximation of functions, abstraction refinement)
name: Modellierung, Analyse, Verifikation

description: efficient techniques to visually represent large-scale data sets from simulation and measurement.
name: Scientific Visualization

description: to understand and to design compilers and interpreters, and to show them the practical problems of compiler construction.
name: Compilerbau

description: how to design and evaluate systems that help humans to cooperate and collaborate with each other.
name: Cooperation Systems

description: This course teaches fundamental programming techniques through modern programming languages like Python. It covers the basic structure of programs, data types and variables, expressions and statements, input and output using pipes and streams, exception handling, functions, and constructs of modern programming languages. Students will learn to transform elementary problem statements into algorithms and implement them in Python and Java. They are expected to produce understandable and well-documented source code in line with standards and conventions.
name: Fundamental Programming Techniques

core_concepts: Natural language to logical formula conversion
description: The course focuses on teaching propositional logic and first-order predicate logic. Students will become familiar with the basic concepts of mathematical logic, learn important theorems like the Compactness Theorem and the undecidability of predicate logic. Emphasis is placed on the algorithmic aspects of logic, such as the resolution method and the fundamentals of logic programming. Students will be able to translate natural language statements into logical formulas and proficiently use tools for automatic proof.
name: Logic

core_concepts: UML diagrams (Petrinetze, class, object, activity, state diagrams)
description: This course introduces essential practical modeling languages, including Petrinetze and key diagram types in UML such as class diagrams, object diagrams, activity diagrams, and state diagrams. Students will learn to visually and mathematically analyze specific diagrams of these languages to identify properties, correct errors, and supplement subsequent steps in dynamic behavior. They can determine the relationships between instances of different diagram types through the application of semantics or presented algorithms, and use modeling techniques to analyze real-world scenarios and create models.
name: Modeling

description: This course provides students with a fundamental understanding of technical informatics necessary for hardware design and analysis. Based on Boolean algebra, students will learn to distinguish the use of 0 and 1 in basic methods of switching algebra for minimizing logical expressions, the application of binary codes in arithmetic processing, representation coding, and the control of functions in computer construction. The design of digital circuits (combinational and sequential) is derived from the understanding of truth tables and characteristic equations of flip-flops. The fundamentals of automata theory lead to microprogramming. Finally, the realization of complex functions required for computer construction is introduced and discussed.
name: Fundamentals of Technical Informatics

core_concepts: Software for circuit design and analysis
description: In this laboratory course, students will use appropriate design and simulation software for digital circuits to explore the capabilities of computer-aided development of digital circuits. In the first step, students will simulate and analyze basic components of digital technology. Based on these experiences, they will design and test simple combinational and sequential circuits.
lecturer: Prof. Dr. Elsa Kirchner, Dipl.-Ing. Joachim Zumbrägel
name: Practical Course of Technical Informatics

description: The course begins by teaching students to handle essential methodological concepts in mathematics, such as logic and proofs. Subsequently, elementary mathematical concepts like sets, relations, and mappings are introduced, and their properties are studied. Based on this knowledge, basic algebraic structures such as groups, rings, and fields, their substructures (subgroups, normal subgroups, ideals), and structure-preserving mappings (homomorphisms) are presented and examined. In the second half of the course, students will learn the essential concepts and methods of linear algebra, including vector spaces, subspaces, bases, dimensions, and linear mappings. These knowledge are applied in matrix calculus and solving linear equation systems. Accompanying the lectures, exercises are provided to reinforce the learned material through tasks and additional examples.
name: Discrete Mathematics 1

description: Building on the fundamental programming techniques learned in an earlier semester, this course deepens students' understanding and application of programming concepts and techniques to more complex problems. It focuses on advanced language elements and APIs in Java. Students will understand object-oriented programming, architecture and design patterns, object serialization and reflection, database connectivity, concurrent programming, and network programming. They will also learn to develop graphical user interfaces using the Model-View-Controller principle, enabling them to implement larger applications in the network and database domains.
name: Advanced Programming Techniques

description: This course introduces the concept of abstract data types, presents important examples of abstract data types, and demonstrates their application in handling fundamental algorithms. Students will learn to explain the concept of algorithms, develop algorithms through stepwise refinement, and distinguish important complexity classes to evaluate the complexity of an algorithm. They will master basic data structures and be able to choose and implement the appropriate representation for a given context, understanding the differences, advantages, and disadvantages of various data structures.
name: Data Structures and Algorithms

description: This course focuses on teaching the fundamentals of analysis. Students will master the knowledge of real and complex numbers, sequences and series, limits, continuity, elementary functions, and differential and integral calculus of functions of one variable through solving related problems. In particular, students will understand that the results obtained from the axiomatic characterization of real numbers need to be treated with caution when applied to computers.
name: Mathematics for Computer Scientists 1

description: The course covers the hardware fundamentals of computer networks, packet transmission technologies, the layered model and protocols, and network applications. Students will understand computer communication based on layered models, be able to assign physical and logical components such as addresses and services to different layers, and identify various communication forms in different architectures. They will learn important access standards and protocol families and understand their significance in data exchange.
lecturer: Dr. Werner Otten, Prof. Dr. Torben Weis
name: Computer Networks and Communication Systems

description: This course provides fundamental knowledge in the fields of computability and complexity. Students will learn different computing models such as Turing machines, LOOP, WHILE, GOTO programs, primitive recursive and mu-recursive functions. Through proving the equivalence of these computing models, they will understand Church's Thesis. They will learn concepts such as undecidability and reducibility, and be able to identify and prove undecidable problems. In the field of complexity theory, they will become familiar with different complexity classes, understand the P-NP problem and the concept of (NP-)completeness, and be able to estimate the complexity of problems and perform simple reductions.
name: Computability and Complexity

core_concepts: Software development life cycle models (V-model, agile methods)
description: This course provides fundamental knowledge in the fields of computability and complexity. Students will learn different computing models such as Turing machines, LOOP, WHILE, GOTO programs, primitive recursive and mu-recursive functions. Through proving the equivalence of these computing models, they will understand Church's Thesis. They will learn concepts such as undecidability and reducibility, and be able to identify and prove undecidable problems. In the field of complexity theory, they will become familiar with different complexity classes, understand the P-NP problem and the concept of (NP-)completeness, and be able to estimate the complexity of problems and perform simple reductions.
lecturer: Prof. Dr. Andreas Metzger, Prof. Dr. Maritta Heisel
name: Software Engineering

description: The course covers fundamental technologies, protocols, architectures, and subsystems for security in communication networks. Students will learn the various aspects of security, master the process of communication protocols starting from key generation and signature methods, and be familiar with the concept of Zero Knowledge Proof. They will be able to identify learned concepts in comprehensive security architectures, handle basic security aspects when accessing computing facilities, and be familiar with important software anomalies and necessary protection measures. Finally, they will analyze the extensions of network protocols for security and privacy features.
lecturer: Dr. Werner Otten, Prof. Dr. Torben Weis
name: Security in Communication Networks

description: Starting from the basic structure of processors and computers, this course introduces the classical architecture of von Neumann computers, presents microcomputers and microprocessor systems up to the modern PC, and covers high-performance computers. Students will understand the structure and operation of current computer hardware, different philosophies of computer architecture, and various approaches to parallelism in computer architectures. They will also learn to program small tasks in assembler.
lecturer: Dr. Werner Otten, Prof. Dr. Torben Weis
name: Computer Architecture

description: This course approaches programming from an algebraic and logical foundation and introduces specific programming languages, including functional programming with Haskell and logical programming with Prolog. Students will learn to implement familiar algorithms in these languages, use abstraction concepts to model problem domains and structure programs appropriately. They will be able to make semantic statements about given programs regarding static correctness and dynamic behavior, and relate programs of different paradigms (functional, logical, imperative) to each other.
name: Programming Paradigms

description: This is an elective course for deepening informatics knowledge. The specific content depends on the students' choices, which may include Internet technology and Web engineering, human-computer interaction, and other fields, aiming to deepen students' understanding and skills in specific areas of informatics.
name: Elective Module for Deepening Informatics 1

description: The course teaches the theories and concepts of operating system design and helps students understand the models for process and memory management in modern operating systems. Students will be able to evaluate the suitability and application of different file systems and peripheral devices, and assess the mechanisms and procedures necessary for operating system security.
lecturer: Dr. Werner Otten, Prof. Torben Weis
name: Operating Systems

description: The course aims to teach students the theory and concepts of relational databases, basic concepts of relational query languages, and the fundamentals of database design. Students will learn to use SQL and methods of database schema design, understand concepts such as views, access rights, and transactions. They will be able to evaluate the suitability and limitations of the relational data model, assess the consequences of database schema changes, and understand the risks of poorly designed DB schemas.
name: Databases

description: In this practical course, students will learn to perform standard tasks of database administration, including defining database schemas, setting access rights, integrity constraints, and database triggers, creating complex SQL queries, developing database application programs, and developing web-based database applications. The course covers the entire process of database development from the conceptual phase to the programming of an application.
name: Database Practice
programming_requirements:
HTML basic
CSS basic
Javascript basic

name: Fehlerdiagnose und Fehlertoleranz in technischen Systemen
